awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Improving farmer safety and grain storage efficiencies via a remote-controlled grain management and extraction robot
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to help farmers across the nation improve their grain storage efficiencies in a remote and safe manner. In addition to demonstrating technical feasibility of a mobile robot, this project may help refine key design considerations such as cost, portability, and usability, that will help promote widespread customer adoption during commercialization.  Though the robot will be initially designed for commonly stored cereal grains in the U.S., this technology may be applied across numerous agriculture-related commodities around the world. The robotics technology has the potential to enhance farmer safety while simultaneously improving grain management practices that yield more efficient and stable food supply chains. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project explores the use of mobile robots for grain storage assessment. Grain bins provide challenging environments for the operation of robots including: dust and temperature extremes, shifting fluid dynamics, and grain quality challenges. The focus of the research includes classifying and characterizing key grain surface variables that impact robotic effectiveness, identifying the top 3-5 grain management tasks by frequency and importance, and analyzing the impacts of grain characteristics on each task, and designing and conducting controlled environmental studies to quantify performance requirements.  The project will also identify and define potential grain engagement paths/patterns for top use case tasks, and analyze potential failure modes for robot operations within grain bins. Once complete, the research may  demonstrate the impact on post-harvest workflows, develop autonomous operations, and build a safe robot platform for use in grain bins.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
With SBIR Phase I Funding, Grain Weevil has demonstrated that improving farmer safety and grain storage efficiencies via a grain management and extraction robot is possible. Grain bins are the permanent long-term grain storage solution for farmers and commercial facilities, there are approximately 1,000,000 in the US alone with the capacity to store nearly 15 billion bushels of grain. They can be a very dangerous enclosed environments, and farmers often have to enter the bins to work on the grain for different reasons. This puts them at risk of grain dust exposure and grain entrapments, which can be harmful or even deadly.  

To address this issue, the team developed the Grain Weevil, a novel grain bin safety and management robot. It is a semi-autonomous robot that uses auger-based propulsion to improve airflow uniformity, smooth out the walls of grain, and break up grain crusts and bridges. During SBIR Phase I testing, Grain Weevil came to the following conclusions: 

  1. Surface based mobile robots can perform the tasks necessary to impact farmer well-being within grain storage environments. 

  2. Robots can have a bigger impact on grain quality management than previously estimated. 

  3. Meeting hazardous location safety standards along with functional safety requirements will directly correlate with research done in Phase I. 

Overall insights include: Making a positive impact on farmer well-being and the financial aspects of grain management requires a robot that can do the work that no farmer should; The grain bin environment dictates a simple machine but the autonomous complexity dictates intelligent capabilities; Grain bins are challenging environments for both humans and robots. Ultimately this research has solidified the importance of Grain Weevil?s safety focused mission: "No Boots in the Grain."

 


Last Modified: 03/31/2023
Modified by: Benjamin H Johnson
